item.title: Book review - 99 Bottles of OOP (2nd Edition)
item.description: I read 99 Bottles of OOP (2nd Edition) and wrote some thoughts about it. Spoiler - I liked it alot!
item.content:encoded:
I read the latest edition of Sandi Metz et al‚Äôs 99 Bottles of OOP. I read the Ruby variant, but there‚Äôs also a JavaScript one. I‚Äôll probably work through that one as well. It‚Äôs that good!

Don‚Äôt Repeat Yourself

First, some context. I‚Äôve been programming professionally for about five years. I read Clean Code and Pragmatic Programmer pretty early on. They appear in pretty much every recommended software developer reading list out there, so they‚Äôre kind of hard to miss.

The advice they contain seems very reasonable. Code should always be clean. Methods should be short, and then they should be even shorter than that. Knowledge should never be repeated (DRY).

This IS good advice, but it isn‚Äôt ALWAYS good advice. When I read the books, I didn‚Äôt have the experience to say ‚Äúyeah, well, it depends‚Äù. Because it always depends. That‚Äôs why you shouldn‚Äôt get dogmatic about these things.

Duplication might be OK

So, what‚Äôs the problem with clean code?

To make code clean/dry, you‚Äôll most certainly have to add a layer of indirection. Or in other words, an abstraction. Abstractions will (hopefully) make the code easier to change, but might make the code harder to read.

Sandi Metz thinks that we should prefer duplication over the wrong abstraction. And that really resonates with me, at this point in my career. We tend to have a lot of respect for existing abstractions. We‚Äôll tack on another parameter and add one more conditional to a function that‚Äôs almost suitable for our use case. This eventually leads to a tangled mess that you‚Äôre afraid to touch.

99 bottles

99 Bottles of OOP is an expansion of this mindset. In essence, you‚Äôll be writing a program that returns the lyrics to the namesake song.

The book‚Äôs first version of the program contains a lot of duplication, but it passes all the tests and is quite easy to read. And that is an excellent place to stop at. If no new requirements arrive at our desk, there‚Äôs no need to abstract the duplication. We should move on and work on other things. I find this immensely refreshing and pragmatic.

The rest of the book hands you new requirements and teaches you how to find good abstractions in the case you should need them. You‚Äôll be TDD-ing new requirements, refactoring code smells, and renaming classes as you learn more and more about the problem. You‚Äôll also be led down a couple of bad paths to show you how that feels, and how you‚Äôll recover. It feels like pair programming with a master, teaching you a long career‚Äôs worth of hard-earned knowledge.

There‚Äôs a lot of discussion about how it feels to write code. Tiny steps backed by tests make the experience stress-free. It makes me think about the seminal books by Kent Beck, which talks a lot about making developers feel safe. If you‚Äôve experienced the stress of diving too far into a hairy code change that just turns everything into an unreadable plate of spaghetti, you‚Äôll appreciate these values.

Takeaways

This book probably isn‚Äôt for everyone. For the right person though, it‚Äôs excellent. A lot of the lessons within will be learned with experience. And if you haven‚Äôt experienced the problems that the book addresses, it might not resonate with you. But for someone with a moderate amount of experience, I think this one really hits home.

The SOLID principles (and relatives) never really stuck with me before. Now I can feel the value of the Open-Closed Principle because this book made me use it to implement changing requirements with ease. I have an intuition for why we should conform to the Law of Demeter. The tests will be way easier to write!

But above all, I feel like I‚Äôve given a license to not abstract stuff I don‚Äôt yet understand. And more importantly, to tear up existing abstractions that smells bad!

item.title: Building some Ruby source code
item.description: Where we add a pointless method to the Ruby language!
item.content:encoded:
In my last post, I fumbled around in the Ruby source code and took a look at an internal function that is not exposed via the public Ruby API. It‚Äôs called ary_make_hash and turns an array into a hash where each key-value pair has the same value.

In imaginary Ruby, it would work like this:

irb> [1, 2, 3].make_hash #(Doesn't exist)
  => {1=>1, 2=>2, 3=>3}

As a learning exercise, let‚Äôs alter the Ruby source so that the example above would actually work!

Building Ruby

First, we gotta be able to build Ruby. There‚Äôs a guide in the repo, but that just resulted in a wall of C compiler errors sprinkled with complaints about the openssl lib. I was just about to desperately try it on a virtual Linux box instead (I‚Äôm running macOS), when I found this.

A detailed guide for getting started on hacking the MRI (the standard Ruby C implementation)! This worked like a charm on the latest release branch (ruby_2_7). I feel like this should be on the official README. Possible pull request coming up!

Hacking Ruby

As we found out last time, the mapping of Ruby method name to C function is located at the bottom of each relevant source file. For example, here‚Äôs the line for Array.to_h. So, let‚Äôs pop in a new line and map it to ary_make_hash:

...
rb_define_method(rb_cArray, "make_hash", ary_make_hash, 0);
...

I‚Äôm not sure what the last argument does, but the regular to_h passes 0, so we‚Äôll probably be fine using that as well.

Try to run it and.. üí• BAM üí•

irb> [1, 2, 3].make_hash

[BUG] Segmentation fault at 0x0000000000000020

(Followed by a million lines of traces and error messages)

A segfault pops up! Not really used to these, but it seems like we‚Äôre trying to read a part of the memory that we shouldn‚Äôt.

However, if we assign the expression to a variable, it works just fine.

irb> hash = [1, 2, 3].make_hash
irb>

Of course, if we try to do anything with the hash variable, everything blows up again. Let‚Äôs look at the source for ary_make_hash:

static VALUE
ary_make_hash(VALUE ary)
{
    VALUE hash = ary_tmp_hash_new(ary);
    return ary_add_hash(hash, ary);
}

Make a temp hash, you say? That sounds suspicious. Let‚Äôs dig deeper:

ary_tmp_hash_new(VALUE ary)
{
    long size = RARRAY_LEN(ary);
    VALUE hash = rb_hash_new_with_size(size);

    RBASIC_CLEAR_CLASS(hash);
    return hash;
}

It looks like we should do fine if we just use the call to rb_hash_new_with_size without calling the clear function afterward. Let‚Äôs make a new function, and name it rb_ary_make_hash to indicate that it‚Äôs visible to Ruby (with the rb_ prefix):

static VALUE
rb_ary_make_hash(VALUE ary)
{
    VALUE hash = rb_hash_new_with_size(RARRAY_LEN(ary));
    return ary_add_hash(hash, ary);
}

And swap the method mapping for our new function:

rb_define_method(rb_cArray, "make_hash", rb_ary_make_hash, 0);

Running Ruby

Moment of truth coming up. Will it work?

irb> [1, 2, 3].make_hash
  => {1=>1, 2=>2, 3=>3}

It actually does!

This is of course pretty pointless, but we figured out how to build, hack and run our own version of Ruby! Next time, we might be able to try something useful!

item.title: Reading some Ruby source code
item.description: Where my quest to avoid learning to write proper hash functions made me dive into the Ruby source.
item.content:encoded:
I‚Äôm a Ruby newbie, learning the language by doing some old Advent of Code puzzles. In one of them, I found the Array - (minus) method to be very useful. In short, it returns the difference between two arrays. My particular use case was to check if every element in the first array was included in the second one, which would return an empty array:

irb> [2, 4] - [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
  => []

However, my elements weren‚Äôt integers but rather custom types. As per the docs, we need to override eql? and hash to make it work.

That got me thinking about how a proper hash function is supposed to work. Some prime number times the hash of every member? Not sure. And that got me thinking even more ‚Äî when would the hash function be used in my case? Under what conditions? Why isn‚Äôt eql? enough?

And then I realized that the actual C source code is listed right there in the docs. Let‚Äôs dive in!

static VALUE
rb_ary_diff(VALUE ary1, VALUE ary2)
{
    VALUE ary3;
    VALUE hash;
    long i;

    ary2 = to_ary(ary2);
    ary3 = rb_ary_new();

    if (RARRAY_LEN(ary1) <= SMALL_ARRAY_LEN || RARRAY_LEN(ary2) <= SMALL_ARRAY_LEN) {
        for (i=0; i<RARRAY_LEN(ary1); i++) {
            VALUE elt = rb_ary_elt(ary1, i);
            if (rb_ary_includes_by_eql(ary2, elt)) continue;
            rb_ary_push(ary3, elt);
        }
        return ary3;
    }

    hash = ary_make_hash(ary2);
    for (i=0; i<RARRAY_LEN(ary1); i++) {
        if (rb_hash_stlike_lookup(hash, RARRAY_AREF(ary1, i), NULL)) continue;
        rb_ary_push(ary3, rb_ary_elt(ary1, i));
    }
    ary_recycle_hash(hash);
    return ary3;
}

I‚Äôm not what you would call a fluent C reader, but we should be able to sort this one out.

The broad strokes are that we supply our two arrays (named ary1 and ary2), diff them, and store the result in ary3 which is returned.

The first bit of conditional logic seems to check if either array is smaller than some constant named SMALL_ARRAY_LEN (if we poke around in the repo, we find that it‚Äôs defined to 16). If so, it will iterate over every element in ary1 and push it into ary3 if it is not included in ary2. The inclusion check is performed by rb_ary_includes_by_eql(ary2, elt), which we probably can assume runs in O(n) time.

Okay, so if the number of elements to check is within reason, we do it the brute force way. So, what if it isn‚Äôt? Then we make a hash (Ruby for dictionary or map) of ary2 and check inclusion in O(1) time!

<üê∞ Rabbit hole>

This raises a question ‚Äî which Ruby method does ary_make_hash correspond to? It certainly isn‚Äôt to_h:

irb> [1, 2, 3].to_h

TypeError (wrong element type Integer at 0 (expected array))

That method expects one array of keys and one array of values. That isn‚Äôt what we‚Äôre doing here.

If we search for ary_make_hash in the repo, we only get matches in the array.c file. Could this mean that it‚Äôs an internal function? Let‚Äôs compare it to a method we know is in the public API, like unshift. Near the bottom of array.c, we find this. Seems like the mapping of Ruby method name to C function. We also notice that every C function exposed this way is prefixed with rb_, like rb_ary_unshift. Now we can be pretty sure that ary_make_hash only is used internally. Let‚Äôs take a look at it!

static VALUE
ary_make_hash(VALUE ary)
{
    VALUE hash = ary_tmp_hash_new(ary);
    return ary_add_hash(hash, ary);
}

static inline VALUE
ary_tmp_hash_new(VALUE ary)
{
    long size = RARRAY_LEN(ary);
    VALUE hash = rb_hash_new_with_size(size);

    RBASIC_CLEAR_CLASS(hash);
    return hash;
}

static VALUE
ary_add_hash(VALUE hash, VALUE ary)
{
    long i;

    for (i=0; i<RARRAY_LEN(ary); i++) {
			VALUE elt = RARRAY_AREF(ary, i);
			rb_hash_add_new_element(hash, elt, elt);
    }
    return hash;
}

ary_make_hash uses two other functions, ary_tmp_hash_new and ary_add_hash. They‚Äôre all listed above, and hopefully, it‚Äôs enough to figure out what‚Äôs going on. ary_tmp_hash_new just creates an empty hash with a size matching the passed array. The solution lies in the line rb_hash_add_new_element(hash, elt, elt); from ary_add_hash ‚Äî we get a hash where the keys and values are the same, e.g:

irb> [1, 2, 3].make_hash #(Doesn't exist)
  => {1=>1, 2=>2, 3=>3}

We probably could have guessed it, but where‚Äôs the fun in that?

</ üê∞ Rabbit hole>

Let‚Äôs return to rb_ary_diff.

static VALUE
rb_ary_diff(VALUE ary1, VALUE ary2)
{
    # other stuff excluded..

    hash = ary_make_hash(ary2);
    for (i=0; i<RARRAY_LEN(ary1); i++) {
        if (rb_hash_stlike_lookup(hash, RARRAY_AREF(ary1, i), NULL)) continue;
        rb_ary_push(ary3, rb_ary_elt(ary1, i));
    }
    ary_recycle_hash(hash);
    return ary3;
}

We make a hash out of ary2. Then we‚Äôll iterate over ary1 and look the elements up in the hash. If they‚Äôre not found, we push them onto ary3. And since we‚Äôre in C land, we got to return the memory for the hash!

This all means that the requested hash override is only ever used if either array is longer than 16 elements, and even then it‚Äôs a performance optimization (a really bad hash function turns a hash into a list). In my case, no array is ever longer than 10 elements, so I can safely ignore overriding it without risking any penalties!

Conclusion

In the quest of avoiding learning how to write a proper hash function, I poked around in the Ruby source code and actually learned a thing or two about how things are organized ‚Äî specifically the naming convention of functions belonging to the public Ruby API. This might be the beginning of a whole lot of Ruby source code spelunking!
